text:
Saudi tourism revenue likely to overtake oil income in future Published on : Saturday, October 3, 2015
Saudi Arabia’s revenues from tourism could overtake its income from oil some day in the future, according to tourism industry experts and economists.
Speaking on the rapid growth of tourism to the country at a Saudi state event, economists and experts said that tourism and national heritage are the sectors most likely to become pillars for Saudi Arabia’s future economy.
“Tourism represents the second most important economic sector in the Kingdom,” said economic analyst Fadl Saad Al Bu Ainaian, according to the Saudi Commission for Tourism and National Heritage (SCTNH).
“Despite its low contribution to the gross domestic product (GDP) of only 2.7 percent, development plans in tourism show its ability to raise its contribution to higher levels, and makes it more capable to develop targeted areas especially the rural and remote areas that need comprehensive economic development to create jobs and investment opportunities,” the economist added.
Another economist present at Saudi’s tourism event, Nasir bin Ogail Al Tayyar, estimated the volume of tourism market in the Kingdom as about 80 billion Saudi riyals — $21.3 billion — aside from the income derived from pilgrims travelling to the Islamic holy site Mecca.
The comments come as Saudi Arabia is investing increasingly in its tourism industry, with the SCTNH overseeing numerous programs to develop museums and heritage sites, tourist accommodation, tourism routes and domestic employment in the tourism and hospitality trade.
Pushing the tourism agenda away from home too, Saudi Prince Sultan bin Salman, the president of the SCTNH, attended a Group of Twenty (G-20) meeting of tourism ministers in Turkey on Wednesday to discuss how to strengthen the tourism sector – which is estimated to account for one in 11 jobs in the world.
Reporting on Saudi Arabia’s economy in September, the international Monetary Fund (IMF) praised the country’s efforts to diversify but urged the government to continue with reforms of the labour market.
